text: The Science Fiction Radio Show A commentary on science fiction today Presented by the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association This is David Cruz Daryl Lane And David Carson On this program we will be talking with author Larry Niven Niven first appeared in print in 1964 And by 1976 he had won the Hugo Award five times He has written a set of stories set in what he calls known space Which are a future history or a series of stories with a common background He has also written several novels and stories not related to the known space series Aside from science fiction Niven has written a fantasy called The Magic Goes Away And co-authored with Jerry Purnell a science fiction rendering of Dante's Inferno Entitled appropriately enough, Inferno Other collaborations with Jerry Purnell include A Moat in God's Eye And the bestseller, Lucifer's Hammer For my first question to you Mr. Niven I'd like to ask if you classify yourself as a hard science fiction writer in the tradition of Hal Clement If you've got to classify me, that's where I fit, yes I would, uh... I suppose all writers resist classification as best they can I do other things too Fantasy Considerable fantasy A great deal more hard science fiction Not much in the way of soft science fiction Uh... Articles, speeches I'm the guy who did a... Uh... Study of the medical problems of breeding Kryptonians Called Man Who Steal, Woman Who Kleenex And I just published The only venture I've ever made into economics A method which would also solve the problem of nuclear waste disposal The idea is to turn the nuclear waste into coins A healthy economy is one in which the money circulates fast You mentioned that you had not written much in the area of soft science fiction Do you think the new wave is past? That fans and writers are turning back to strongly science-oriented stories? Yes, I do However, the new wave was very good to me When I was first getting started, I was the only new hard science fiction writer The new wave is a very persuasive thing Uh... And very easy to use to justify bad stories I think that's what killed it Not... Not that, uh... Not that increased characterization And experiments with, uh... Typography and story format Are a bad thing in themselves But it's so easy to use New wave to justify a bad story It was bound to collapse How did you begin writing science fiction? Were you always a science fiction reader? A fan? Yes And presently I found I was making up I was daydreaming stories that seemed worth writing Did you tell the stories to others before you gained enough confidence to write them down? Yes I've been a storyteller all my life You have a large and involved fan following Do you ever write specifically for them? Or do you write only what you want to? I mostly write for myself For an imaginary reader who resembles me a great deal Only he needs things explained to him Beyond that, uh... I sell it where I can And pick up readers where I can Let's turn to your known space series for a moment How did you get started writing a future history? Well, there had been future histories around Uh, Poole Andersons and, uh, Robert Heinlein And I tell you I guess we each evolve the, uh, idea somewhat independently And the idea is that if you carved out a consistent Workable future It seems a shame to waste it on one story You put in the background because you want the, uh... You want the, uh... Background of a story to seem bigger than it is So there are things that are simply unexplained And if you think of more to say on a given subject Why you go with it And if you think of a story that fits into the background of a previous story It allows you to elaborate on that background Sometimes you fall in love with the background And presently you've got a bunch of stories that link In the afterword of Ringworld Engineers You said that your known space series was completed Is that still true? And if so, why? I've given up saying that the, uh... That the known space series is dead There's just no point in it I've written five books worth of known space stories since I said that And besides that, I have no doubt that I'll come up with stories Said in the, in Gildly Arms time I like writing science fiction detective stories It just, it's just hard work I do not have a detective story in my head It'll have to emerge But that's the beginning of known space And I'll continue to work with it where it looks like fun You have, as you mentioned, written science fiction detective stories And you've experimented with humor in science fiction Is there any subject area that you think can't be handled well in the science fiction genre? No, I can't think of any I guess I go along with the idea that there are these interlocked circles To represent various areas of fiction And they all swim in the sea of fantasy Science fiction probably includes the entire portion of fantasy that is possible And, uh, mainstream would be somewhere in there Nurse novels would be somewhere in that There would be no subject you could treat in English That couldn't be treated in a science fiction format Except, uh, fantasy And that would be treated in a fantasy format Probably your best known work in the known space series is Ringworld Can you tell us how that concept came about? Oh, I ran across the concept Dyson sphere Dyson, the mathematician, came up with the concept Dyson shell And he was misunderstood to some extent So, presently I ran across an article about Dyson spheres Picture that as a golf ball 93 million miles in radius With a sun at the center And gravity generators all around the outside So you would live on the inside Terraform it with, uh, oceans and soil and air I ran across that and I didn't like it I thought it could be improved And I wound up with the Ringworld Freeman Dyson, in commenting on your adaptation of his idea Said that a great number of small Ringworlds would be better than the large one that you had I believe I gave an acceptable answer to that In, uh, the Ringworld engineers But in general he'd be right It's just that the, uh, Ringworld engineers in particular Are people who like dependable weapons of huge size Many of your fans pointed out a number of mistakes and made many elaborations on the concept of the Ringworld Can you tell us what some of them were and how they were corrected or worked into the sequel? For instance I suspected the Ringworld was unstable And I suspected you'd need attitude jets I was sure that, uh, the Ringworld was spinning fast enough to permit Blizzard Ramjets to be used as attitude jets Which means you don't have a fuel problem at all You're burning the solar wind But, uh, rapidly some MIT people demonstrated that the Ringworld was unstable And they were chanting it in the halls at, uh, at the next Worldcon The Ringworld is unstable The Ringworld is unstable Uh, it still took about seven years for anyone to figure out the exact numbers for the instability And they are horrifying The Ringworld, uh, a major solar flare would have the Ringworld grinding against its own Sun in five years Hmm Well, I worked it into the plot That was one, uh, elaboration Or error Another Just can't be correct It seems that there's too much twilight with the shadow squares set up the way I have them set up You get too much of neither day nor night but twilight Uh, half the sun's showing Part of the sun's showing The shadow squares The shadow squares ought to be set up with about five big shadow squares Moving in a retrograde world That way you get day and night setting much faster When it, when it sets Terminator line moves like a bat out of hell It's still a little fuzzy but it doesn't matter Uh, third point Somebody pointed out that, uh, the tensile strength Necessary to hold the Ringworld together is on the order of the, uh, tensile strength of an atomic nucleus It's the super strong force Okay, I can live with that I can postulate that I knew Skrith would have to be stronger than any normal material already Uh, fourth point Some, uh, a high school class in Florida got to work on the Ringworld And their conclusion was that the Ringworld's worst problem is that all the topsoil would wind up in the oceans in about 3,000 years There are no earthquakes on the, uh, Ringworld No mountain building forces Okay, uh, that's a tough one Then I set up a spill pipe system That runs the top, that runs the sea bottom muck from the sea bottoms under the Ringworld and up over the edge of the rim wall That even allows you some, uh, some mines Accumulation of, uh, useful metals What else? Checking in my head I find, uh, Frank Gasparic's suggestion That a machine building culture on the Ringworld which reached our level Wouldn't have any petroleum products to use They would wind up using alcohol Of where we use gasoline And, fine, I can live with that As a matter of fact, the sludge From, uh, making alcohol for automobiles The sludge can be used to make plastics Maybe Plastic-like substances, maybe Uh, the chemicals are just as elaborate as those, as the residues from petroleum What else? Still checking in my head I pick up on other things I can't use Such as Dan Alderson's solar system Which involves four Ringworlds He's got three Ringworlds about the size of mine Rotating orthogonally on frictionless bearings And the fourth Ringworld is, uh, about the size of the orbit of Jupiter And inhabited by mesclinites Mesclinites derived from a novel by Hal Clement Mission of Gravity And mesclinites And mesclinites require, uh, cold temperatures About those of the orbit of Jupiter As opposed to Jupiter, which has an internal heat source Cold temperatures and heavy gravity So there's, so his fourth Ringworld is the size of the orbit of Jupiter And spinning like a bat out of hell I had it figured out that if, if they spun that Ringworld any faster It would get nearer the speed of light and contract Dan says I've misunderstood relativity It would not contract Okay, I still haven't figured out why not Well, you obviously enjoy playing the game, as Hal Clement calls it Between your own scientific knowledge and that of your readers and peers Absolutely I incorporated everything that sounded good that I could use In, in, elaborating the design of the Ringworld What do you think about the current ideas for space habitats That are proposed by Gerard O'Neil and others? I think they are grandiose And I certainly wouldn't stop him But the space program seems to have fallen flat on its face at this point We will have trouble reaching the moon again Getting back to the moon is as big a problem as we can face I resent having to say that But I believe it's true Let's turn for a moment to another of your novels One written with Jerry Purnell The Moat in God's Eye How do you go about constructing an alien like the Moaties? Were you influenced by anyone in that area? The Moaties was... no Not in that case In that case, I had the idea that I was following a progression With a protozoan, with an amoeba You get radio symmetry inside and out Move up a goodly distance and you find starfishes with radio symmetry on the outside And bilateral symmetry on the inside Move up a little further, you find flat worms and worms of all stamps At the level of bilateral symmetry inside and out Go as far as a human, you find bilateral symmetry on the outside And no symmetry, well, half symmetrical on the inside The lungs look symmetrical, the kidneys look symmetrical The intestines look like somebody dropped a plate of spaghetti I tried to move on to the next step Bilaterally unsymmetrical on the outside And I got the original Moaties, which was the engineer for them But I always design aliens for themselves I almost never design an alien to match a story The story... some story will eventually include the alien The alien stands for himself I think that one of the outstanding aspects of the Moaties was their non-use of standardized machines They would create whatever replacement parts that they needed on the spot Do you recall what caused you to think along those lines for your alien society? I was just playing along I was just playing with ideas at that point And that one seemed like a fun one It also seemed likely enough If you've got a critter with not much intelligence except in the direction of tool making and tool altering Then, uh, why not? The thing has to keep testing its ability or it will lose it It might as well be designing something every time it needs a specific machine The master can always stop it and have it producing it as if by assembly line If a master needs a lot of somethings fast In Ringworld you developed something called the T. LeBron gene Humans bred to be lucky Was that just a story gimmick or were you extrapolating on the evolution of humanity? Oh... Partly that and partly you've got to remember the time I was writing you I was damn sick and tired of psychic powers showing up in stories I did not believe in psychic powers at that time I've been told they look pretty good now But, uh, at the time I really, I conceived the T. LeBron gene as being the ultimate psychic power Which you may interpret either as luck or as author control And, in that sense, it was something of a put on Except that I can believe almost anything while I'm writing the story And I am able to extrapolate So if T. LeBron is lucky certain things emerge And if she's just a statistical fuk Then something else emerges And that's that people will interpret anything that happens to her as lucky Defending their preconceptions What do you consider to be your best work or your favorite work? No, I couldn't tell you that There is no way I can name a favorite work The whole... My career is a progression for one thing I'd take any novel or any important short story even And out of that progression And it wanders away in a different direction So, I don't think I have a favorite story But I suppose I can name Inconstant Moon One, uh, which is virtually the only strictly love story I've ever done And I suppose I could name Lucifer's Hammer Which made me the most money So, uh, a modem gods I may beat that I suppose I could name, uh, Oh, Man of Steel, Woman of Kleenex Which has gotten me the most laugh, I suppose Everybody seems to have read it And those who haven't have heard about it A cocktail party Or... What? Uh, Jerry Pornell and I just recently wrote The last ten minutes for a movie that had a good 90 minutes Followed by a bad last ten minutes And the last I've heard is they're not gonna make the movie Which is a dirty shame That is, they're not gonna make the last ten minutes our way They're gonna fiddle with what they've got And that's a really dirty shame What they've got is garbage I really hope they'll use that last ten minutes And if they do, I will get considerable enjoyment out of that And that'll be my favorite, you name it You mentioned your collaboration with Jerry Pornell Which do you prefer, writing alone or with another author? I prefer variety I prefer variety I even prefer variety and my collaborators I just finished a novel with a Stephen Barnes And we're starting another A short one And Jerry and I are starting another Almost instantly A novel about, uh Well, we've designed an alien That could invade the earth And also would want It's tough to get an alien Whom you could believe Would want to invade the earth From another star Considering the distances involved And the energies involved And the penalties for failure And the lack of The unlikelihood that it would do your home planet any good If you conquer something that is six light years away Anyway, we've designed one And we will be writing a novel about that When writing in collaboration Is it difficult to decide who writes what? It's hard sometimes But it always resolves The question is who is most qualified to write a given scene That we have both decided needs writing Before we start, we have the novel all laid out We know what's going in virtually everywhere And if we don't, it feels like we do And if we find out we don't We elaborate as we get to that section Okay, the next question is who is qualified to write a given scene? Sometimes it's obvious If we're dealing with a madman, he's mine If we're dealing with military operations, it's Jerry's Aliens are generally mine Politics is generally Jerry's Knowledge of history generally Jerry's And a real evil son of a bitch Jerry usually creates him And I usually run with him afterwards Because Jerry has a lot of textbooks on psychology And a PhD in psychology for that matter Sorry, doctorate in psychology And when he's created a really evil son of a bitch He just hates him too much to work with him I can usually do something Horace Barry went that way And the rapist in Lucifer's Hammer And a couple other characters in Inferno I understand that both you and Mr. Purnell use computer word processors How does that aid in your writing? It makes first draft a little faster But it makes corrections enormously faster You get a more polished novel when I'm using a word processor It's polishing is just like thinking into the machine almost Uh, the word processor behaves like a magic typewriter It does everything you would want a typewriter to do Only it can't It can't erase whole blocks of print at a time And then straighten up the page so it looks like you never made any corrections But a word processor can do just that And move blocks up and down the page Up and down the manuscript What do you think, Mr. Newman, is the future of science fiction? Has fantasy begun taking over or is there a lot more hard science fiction to come? Hard to say For one thing, uh, writers in general don't take orders worth a damn The science fiction field is galloping off in all directions just as it always has And the reader will make the final decision in most cases What will be successful, it will depend on who buys what books That's always been true I understand that some of your works were involved several years ago with the animated Star Trek series How did that come about? Oh, it went like this Uh, they were gonna start a Star Trek cartoon And, uh, the lady who was story editor got me involved I tried to give them a story that involved a mini black hole and, uh, an outsider ship I had the idea that Star Trek had been using men in rubber suits for so long That they wouldn't realize how much more freedom they had with the animated version That turns out not to be the case They had some very good aliens in there But, uh, that story turned out to be a little over, over the heads of their intended audience So, I wound, uh, it, it did incidentally wind up as, as the first version of the, uh, last part of a story called The Borderlands Soul So, I eventually wound up meeting Gene Roddenberry And he wound up suggesting, why don't I take a story called The Soft Weapon And turn it into a, into a Star Trek version And I did that, and called it The Slaver Weapon And, fine, they, they eventually made a cartoon out of it They also sold the right to turn that cartoon script into a story They sold that to Ballantyne I got mildly upset The president of the CIFIL, who was Jerry Pornell at the time, got seriously upset And started making as many waves as he could And, what eventually happened was that they sent me a dollar for, uh, a check for two dollars and something something cents Somewhere between two and three dollars And, Jerry, I don't know where the negotiations went But Jerry wound up saying, okay, that defends the principle of the thing, uh, we'll ask for more next time And that's, that for some years By, by then I had written to Ballantyne and gotten a letter from Betty Ballantyne saying, Hey, we, we won't ever use it We promise, we see you're upset We promise we won't ever do anything with this A little later, the Ballantyne got out of the, uh, Ballantyne books business And, and into the business of printing, uh, illustrated stuff And Judy Lindell Ray wound up in charge And presently, presently, I'm being offered 2,000 bucks as advisor to Alan Dean Foster Who will turn my script into a novel And, I said fine, when I, what I really meant was acceptable A few months later, I've got a letter from Judy Lind dropping the price to 500 and I blew my top I said, A, I won't collaborate with, with, uh, you or Alan on anything of the kind And B, you may not use anything from known space except what's in the script And that is the way it happened Are there any plans for motion picture or television adaptations of any of your works in the near future? Yes, there are Uh, I just don't know how far they are going to go But there is, there is a group that owns an option on, on Death by Ecstasy And a guy who owns an option on The Mode in God's Eye And, let's see, I've got a friend trying to get a public broadcasting system To make a TV version of Lucifer, of, uh, In Constant Moon Which would be nice, all of which would be nice Are there any contemporary writers that you particularly enjoy reading? Yes, a great many Ursula Le Guin, John Varley, Poole Anderson, uh, Jerry Pornell Uh, how far do we go with this? I like the old ones and I like the new ones I like about half of, uh, Ronald Ellison's stories Which is a better record than many writers have I like a few of Phil Dixon's stories And I will probably buy the, uh, Last of the Dorsi books by Gordie Dixon In fact, it's damn certain I will read it I'll buy it if it doesn't come free I, I'm swamped in free books, you know Uh, I'm a Piers Anthony fan I don't know how numerous we Piers Anthony fans are Uh, I like the puzzles in his books And his books are always jammed with puzzles And new ways of thinking And so forth One last question, I don't suppose those Piers and Puppeteers Ever snuck you the formula for the General Products hole, did they? No, I don't have the formula for the General Products hole But I've, I've reason to suspect that there are Puppeteers on Earth Uh, look at their characteristics Uh, forget the shape, they must be masters of biology To hide that peculiar three-legged, two-headed shape But consider their characteristics They are cowards That is, they want everything utterly safe No corners on anything Everything is soft surfaces around the puppeteer world Uh, they don't even keep their world near a sun Regarding it as a runaway, uh, fusion reactor Which of course it is So, uh, desperate regard for safety They, uh, plus an urge to meddle in the lifestyles of other species Driving urge to, to meddle with, with, uh, practically no restraints on the planet And the remains attached What does that remind you of? It seems nearly certain to me that Ralph Nader is a Pearson Spuppeteer This is David Cruz Daryl Lang And David Carson This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show A presentation of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association In conjunction with KOCV-FM And Odessa College, Odessa, Texas

segments.text: The Science Fiction Radio Show
A commentary on science fiction today
Presented by the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association
This is David Cruz
Daryl Lane
And David Carson
On this program we will be talking with author Larry Niven
Niven first appeared in print in 1964
And by 1976 he had won the Hugo Award five times
He has written a set of stories set in what he calls known space
Which are a future history or a series of stories with a common background
He has also written several novels and stories not related to the known space series
Aside from science fiction
Niven has written a fantasy called The Magic Goes Away
And co-authored with Jerry Purnell a science fiction rendering of Dante's Inferno
Entitled appropriately enough, Inferno
Other collaborations with Jerry Purnell include
A Moat in God's Eye
And the bestseller, Lucifer's Hammer
For my first question to you Mr. Niven
I'd like to ask if you classify yourself as a hard science fiction writer in the tradition of Hal Clement
If you've got to classify me, that's where I fit, yes
I would, uh...
I suppose all writers resist classification as best they can
I do other things too
Fantasy
Considerable fantasy
A great deal more hard science fiction
Not much in the way of soft science fiction
Uh...
Articles, speeches
I'm the guy who did a...
Uh...
Study of the medical problems of breeding Kryptonians
Called Man Who Steal, Woman Who Kleenex
And I just published
The only venture I've ever made into economics
A method which would also solve the problem of nuclear waste disposal
The idea is to turn the nuclear waste into coins
A healthy economy is one in which the money circulates fast
You mentioned that you had not written much in the area of soft science fiction
Do you think the new wave is past?
That fans and writers are turning back to strongly science-oriented stories?
Yes, I do
However, the new wave was very good to me
When I was first getting started, I was the only new hard science fiction writer
The new wave is a very persuasive thing
Uh...
And very easy to use to justify bad stories
I think that's what killed it
Not...
Not that, uh...
Not that increased characterization
And experiments with, uh...
Typography and story format
Are a bad thing in themselves
But it's so easy to use
New wave to justify a bad story
It was bound to collapse
How did you begin writing science fiction?
Were you always a science fiction reader?
A fan?
Yes
And presently I found I was making up
I was daydreaming stories that seemed worth writing
Did you tell the stories to others before you gained enough confidence to write them down?
Yes
I've been a storyteller all my life
You have a large and involved fan following
Do you ever write specifically for them?
Or do you write only what you want to?
I mostly write for myself
For an imaginary reader who resembles me a great deal
Only he needs things explained to him
Beyond that, uh...
I sell it where I can
And pick up readers where I can
Let's turn to your known space series for a moment
How did you get started writing a future history?
Well, there had been future histories around
Uh, Poole Andersons and, uh, Robert Heinlein
And
I tell you
I guess we each evolve the, uh, idea somewhat independently
And the idea is that if you carved out a consistent
Workable future
It seems a shame to waste it on one story
You put in the background because you want the, uh...
You want the, uh...
Background of a story to seem bigger than it is
So there are things that are simply unexplained
And if you think of more to say on a given subject
Why you go with it
And if you think of a story that fits into the background of a previous story
It allows you to elaborate on that background
Sometimes you fall in love with the background
And presently you've got a bunch of stories that link
In the afterword of Ringworld Engineers
You said that your known space series was completed
Is that still true?
And if so, why?
I've given up saying that the, uh...
That the known space series is dead
There's just no point in it
I've written five books worth of known space stories since I said that
And besides that, I have no doubt that I'll come up with stories
Said in the, in Gildly Arms time
I like writing science fiction detective stories
It just, it's just hard work
I do not have a detective story in my head
It'll have to emerge
But that's the beginning of known space
And I'll continue to work with it where it looks like fun
You have, as you mentioned, written science fiction detective stories
And you've experimented with humor in science fiction
Is there any subject area that you think can't be handled well in the science fiction genre?
No, I can't think of any
I guess I go along with the idea that there are these interlocked circles
To represent various areas of fiction
And they all swim in the sea of fantasy
Science fiction probably includes the entire portion of fantasy that is possible
And, uh, mainstream would be somewhere in there
Nurse novels would be somewhere in that
There would be no subject you could treat in English
That couldn't be treated in a science fiction format
Except, uh, fantasy
And that would be treated in a fantasy format
Probably your best known work in the known space series is Ringworld
Can you tell us how that concept came about?
Oh, I ran across the concept Dyson sphere
Dyson, the mathematician, came up with the concept Dyson shell
And he was misunderstood to some extent
So, presently I ran across an article about Dyson spheres
Picture that as a golf ball 93 million miles in radius
With a sun at the center
And gravity generators all around the outside
So you would live on the inside
Terraform it with, uh, oceans and soil and air
I ran across that and I didn't like it
I thought it could be improved
And I wound up with the Ringworld
Freeman Dyson, in commenting on your adaptation of his idea
Said that a great number of small Ringworlds would be better than the large one that you had
I believe I gave an acceptable answer to that
In, uh, the Ringworld engineers
But in general he'd be right
It's just that the, uh, Ringworld engineers in particular
Are people who like dependable weapons of huge size
Many of your fans pointed out a number of mistakes and made many elaborations on the concept of the Ringworld
Can you tell us what some of them were and how they were corrected or worked into the sequel?
For instance
I suspected the Ringworld was unstable
And I suspected you'd need attitude jets
I was sure that, uh, the Ringworld was spinning fast enough to permit
Blizzard Ramjets to be used as attitude jets
Which means you don't have a fuel problem at all
You're burning the solar wind
But, uh, rapidly some MIT people demonstrated that the Ringworld was unstable
And they were chanting it in the halls at, uh, at the next Worldcon
The Ringworld is unstable
The Ringworld is unstable
Uh, it still took about seven years for anyone to figure out the exact numbers for the instability
And they are horrifying
The Ringworld, uh, a major solar flare would have the Ringworld grinding against its own
Sun in five years
Hmm
Well, I worked it into the plot
That was one, uh, elaboration
Or error
Another
Just can't be correct
It seems that there's too much twilight with the shadow squares set up the way I have them set up
You get too much of neither day nor night but twilight
Uh, half the sun's showing
Part of the sun's showing
The shadow squares
The shadow squares ought to be set up with about five big shadow squares
Moving in a retrograde world
That way you get day and night setting much faster
When it, when it sets
Terminator line moves like a bat out of hell
It's still a little fuzzy but it doesn't matter
Uh, third point
Somebody pointed out that, uh, the tensile strength
Necessary to hold the Ringworld together is on the order of the, uh, tensile strength of an atomic nucleus
It's the super strong force
Okay, I can live with that
I can postulate that
I knew
Skrith would have to be stronger than any normal material already
Uh, fourth point
Some, uh, a high school class in Florida got to work on the Ringworld
And their conclusion was that the Ringworld's worst problem is that all the topsoil would wind up in the oceans in about 3,000 years
There are no earthquakes on the, uh, Ringworld
No mountain building forces
Okay, uh, that's a tough one
Then I set up a spill pipe system
That runs the top, that runs the sea bottom muck from the sea bottoms under the Ringworld and up over the edge of the rim wall
That even allows you some, uh, some mines
Accumulation of, uh, useful metals
What else?
Checking in my head
I find, uh, Frank Gasparic's suggestion
That a machine building culture on the Ringworld which reached our level
Wouldn't have any petroleum products to use
They would wind up using alcohol
Of where we use gasoline
And, fine, I can live with that
As a matter of fact, the sludge
From, uh, making alcohol for automobiles
The sludge can be used to make plastics
Maybe
Plastic-like substances, maybe
Uh, the chemicals are just as elaborate as those, as the residues from petroleum
What else?
Still checking in my head
I pick up on other things I can't use
Such as Dan Alderson's solar system
Which involves four Ringworlds
He's got three Ringworlds about the size of mine
Rotating orthogonally on frictionless bearings
And the fourth Ringworld is, uh, about the size of the orbit of Jupiter
And inhabited by mesclinites
Mesclinites derived from a novel by Hal Clement
Mission of Gravity
And mesclinites
And mesclinites require, uh, cold temperatures
About those of the orbit of Jupiter
As opposed to Jupiter, which has an internal heat source
Cold temperatures and heavy gravity
So there's, so his fourth Ringworld is the size of the orbit of Jupiter
And spinning like a bat out of hell
I had it figured out that if, if they spun that Ringworld any faster
It would get nearer the speed of light and contract
Dan says I've misunderstood relativity
It would not contract
Okay, I still haven't figured out why not
Well, you obviously enjoy playing the game, as Hal Clement calls it
Between your own scientific knowledge and that of your readers and peers
Absolutely
I incorporated everything that sounded good that I could use
In, in, elaborating the design of the Ringworld
What do you think about the current ideas for space habitats
That are proposed by Gerard O'Neil and others?
I think they are grandiose
And I certainly wouldn't stop him
But the space program seems to have fallen flat on its face at this point
We will have trouble reaching the moon again
Getting back to the moon is as big a problem as we can face
I resent having to say that
But I believe it's true
Let's turn for a moment to another of your novels
One written with Jerry Purnell
The Moat in God's Eye
How do you go about constructing an alien like the Moaties?
Were you influenced by anyone in that area?
The Moaties was... no
Not in that case
In that case, I had the idea that
I was following a progression
With a protozoan, with an amoeba
You get radio symmetry inside and out
Move up a goodly distance and you find starfishes with radio symmetry on the outside
And bilateral symmetry on the inside
Move up a little further, you find flat worms and worms of all stamps
At the level of bilateral symmetry inside and out
Go as far as a human, you find bilateral symmetry on the outside
And no symmetry, well, half symmetrical on the inside
The lungs look symmetrical, the kidneys look symmetrical
The intestines look like somebody dropped a plate of spaghetti
I tried to move on to the next step
Bilaterally unsymmetrical on the outside
And I got the original Moaties, which was the engineer for them
But I always design aliens for themselves
I almost never design an alien to match a story
The story... some story will eventually include the alien
The alien stands for himself
I think that one of the outstanding aspects of the Moaties was their non-use of standardized machines
They would create whatever replacement parts that they needed on the spot
Do you recall what caused you to think along those lines for your alien society?
I was just playing along
I was just playing with ideas at that point
And that one seemed like a fun one
It also seemed likely enough
If you've got a critter with not much intelligence except in the direction of tool making and tool altering
Then, uh, why not?
The thing has to keep testing its ability or it will lose it
It might as well be designing something every time it needs a specific machine
The master can always stop it and have it producing it as if by assembly line
If a master needs a lot of somethings fast
In Ringworld you developed something called the T. LeBron gene
Humans bred to be lucky
Was that just a story gimmick or were you extrapolating on the evolution of humanity?
Oh...
Partly that and partly you've got to remember the time I was writing you
I was damn sick and tired of psychic powers showing up in stories
I did not believe in psychic powers at that time
I've been told they look pretty good now
But, uh, at the time
I really, I conceived the T. LeBron gene as being the ultimate psychic power
Which you may interpret either as luck or as author control
And, in that sense, it was something of a put on
Except that I can believe almost anything while I'm writing the story
And I am able to extrapolate
So if T. LeBron is lucky certain things emerge
And if she's just a statistical fuk
Then something else emerges
And that's that people will interpret anything that happens to her as lucky
Defending their preconceptions
What do you consider to be your best work or your favorite work?
No, I couldn't tell you that
There is no way I can name a favorite work
The whole...
My career is a progression for one thing
I'd take any novel or any important short story even
And out of that progression
And it wanders away in a different direction
So, I don't think I have a favorite story
But I suppose I can name Inconstant Moon
One, uh, which is virtually the only strictly love story I've ever done
And I suppose I could name Lucifer's Hammer
Which made me the most money
So, uh, a modem gods I may beat that
I suppose I could name, uh,
Oh, Man of Steel, Woman of Kleenex
Which has gotten me the most laugh, I suppose
Everybody seems to have read it
And those who haven't have heard about it
A cocktail party
Or...
What?
Uh, Jerry Pornell and I just recently wrote
The last ten minutes for a movie that had a good 90 minutes
Followed by a bad last ten minutes
And the last I've heard is they're not gonna make the movie
Which is a dirty shame
That is, they're not gonna make the last ten minutes our way
They're gonna fiddle with what they've got
And that's a really dirty shame
What they've got is garbage
I really hope they'll use that last ten minutes
And if they do, I will get considerable enjoyment out of that
And that'll be my favorite, you name it
You mentioned your collaboration with Jerry Pornell
Which do you prefer, writing alone or with another author?
I prefer variety
I prefer variety
I even prefer variety and my collaborators
I just finished a novel with a Stephen Barnes
And we're starting another
A short one
And Jerry and I are starting another
Almost instantly
A novel about, uh
Well, we've designed an alien
That could invade the earth
And also would want
It's tough to get an alien
Whom you could believe
Would want to invade the earth
From another star
Considering the distances involved
And the energies involved
And the penalties for failure
And the lack of
The unlikelihood that it would do your home planet any good
If you conquer something that is six light years away
Anyway, we've designed one
And we will be writing a novel about that
When writing in collaboration
Is it difficult to decide who writes what?
It's hard sometimes
But it always resolves
The question is who is most qualified to write a given scene
That we have both decided needs writing
Before we start, we have the novel all laid out
We know what's going in virtually everywhere
And if we don't, it feels like we do
And if we find out we don't
We elaborate as we get to that section
Okay, the next question is who is qualified to write a given scene?
Sometimes it's obvious
If we're dealing with a madman, he's mine
If we're dealing with military operations, it's Jerry's
Aliens are generally mine
Politics is generally Jerry's
Knowledge of history generally Jerry's
And a real evil son of a bitch
Jerry usually creates him
And I usually run with him afterwards
Because Jerry has a lot of textbooks on psychology
And a PhD in psychology for that matter
Sorry, doctorate in psychology
And when he's created a really evil son of a bitch
He just hates him too much to work with him
I can usually do something
Horace Barry went that way
And the rapist in Lucifer's Hammer
And a couple other characters in Inferno
I understand that both you and Mr. Purnell use computer word processors
How does that aid in your writing?
It makes first draft a little faster
But it makes corrections enormously faster
You get a more polished novel when I'm using a word processor
It's polishing is just like thinking into the machine almost
Uh, the word processor behaves like a magic typewriter
It does everything you would want a typewriter to do
Only it can't
It can't erase whole blocks of print at a time
And then straighten up the page so it looks like you never made any corrections
But a word processor can do just that
And move blocks up and down the page
Up and down the manuscript
What do you think, Mr. Newman, is the future of science fiction?
Has fantasy begun taking over or is there a lot more hard science fiction to come?
Hard to say
For one thing, uh, writers in general don't take orders worth a damn
The science fiction field is galloping off in all directions just as it always has
And the reader will make the final decision in most cases
What will be successful, it will depend on who buys what books
That's always been true
I understand that some of your works were involved several years ago with the animated Star Trek series
How did that come about?
Oh, it went like this
Uh, they were gonna start a Star Trek cartoon
And, uh, the lady who was story editor got me involved
I tried to give them a story that involved a mini black hole and, uh, an outsider ship
I had the idea that Star Trek had been using men in rubber suits for so long
That they wouldn't realize how much more freedom they had with the animated version
That turns out not to be the case
They had some very good aliens in there
But, uh, that story turned out to be a little over, over the heads of their intended audience
So, I wound, uh, it, it did incidentally wind up as, as the first version of the, uh, last part of a story called The Borderlands Soul
So, I eventually wound up meeting Gene Roddenberry
And he wound up suggesting, why don't I take a story called The Soft Weapon
And turn it into a, into a Star Trek version
And I did that, and called it The Slaver Weapon
And, fine, they, they eventually made a cartoon out of it
They also sold the right to turn that cartoon script into a story
They sold that to Ballantyne
I got mildly upset
The president of the CIFIL, who was Jerry Pornell at the time, got seriously upset
And started making as many waves as he could
And, what eventually happened was that they sent me a dollar for, uh, a check for two dollars and something something cents
Somewhere between two and three dollars
And, Jerry, I don't know where the negotiations went
But Jerry wound up saying, okay, that defends the principle of the thing, uh, we'll ask for more next time
And that's, that for some years
By, by then I had written to Ballantyne and gotten a letter from Betty Ballantyne saying,
Hey, we, we won't ever use it
We promise, we see you're upset
We promise we won't ever do anything with this
A little later, the Ballantyne got out of the, uh, Ballantyne books business
And, and into the business of printing, uh, illustrated stuff
And Judy Lindell Ray wound up in charge
And presently, presently, I'm being offered 2,000 bucks as advisor to Alan Dean Foster
Who will turn my script into a novel
And, I said fine, when I, what I really meant was acceptable
A few months later, I've got a letter from Judy Lind dropping the price to 500 and I blew my top
I said, A, I won't collaborate with, with, uh, you or Alan on anything of the kind
And B, you may not use anything from known space except what's in the script
And that is the way it happened
Are there any plans for motion picture or television adaptations of any of your works in the near future?
Yes, there are
Uh, I just don't know how far they are going to go
But there is, there is a group that owns an option on, on Death by Ecstasy
And a guy who owns an option on The Mode in God's Eye
And, let's see, I've got a friend trying to get a public broadcasting system
To make a TV version of Lucifer, of, uh, In Constant Moon
Which would be nice, all of which would be nice
Are there any contemporary writers that you particularly enjoy reading?
Yes, a great many
Ursula Le Guin, John Varley, Poole Anderson, uh, Jerry Pornell
Uh, how far do we go with this?
I like the old ones and I like the new ones
I like about half of, uh, Ronald Ellison's stories
Which is a better record than many writers have
I like a few of Phil Dixon's stories
And I will probably buy the, uh, Last of the Dorsi books by Gordie Dixon
In fact, it's damn certain I will read it
I'll buy it if it doesn't come free
I, I'm swamped in free books, you know
Uh, I'm a Piers Anthony fan
I don't know how numerous we Piers Anthony fans are
Uh, I like the puzzles in his books
And his books are always jammed with puzzles
And new ways of thinking
And so forth
One last question, I don't suppose those Piers and Puppeteers
Ever snuck you the formula for the General Products hole, did they?
No, I don't have the formula for the General Products hole
But I've, I've reason to suspect that there are Puppeteers on Earth
Uh, look at their characteristics
Uh, forget the shape, they must be masters of biology
To hide that peculiar three-legged, two-headed shape
But consider their characteristics
They are cowards
That is, they want everything utterly safe
No corners on anything
Everything is soft surfaces around the puppeteer world
Uh, they don't even keep their world near a sun
Regarding it as a runaway, uh, fusion reactor
Which of course it is
So, uh, desperate regard for safety
They, uh, plus an urge to meddle in the lifestyles of other species
Driving urge to, to meddle with, with, uh, practically no restraints on the planet
And the remains attached
What does that remind you of?
It seems nearly certain to me that Ralph Nader is a Pearson Spuppeteer
This is David Cruz
Daryl Lang
And David Carson
